awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Biological Interactions from Molecules to Ecosystems- Phenotype, Genotype, and Environment
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to the University of Wisconsin-Madison, located in Madison, WI, will support the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2021- 2023. It is anticipated that a total of 30 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities or from an underrepresented group, will be trained in the program. Students will investigate how diversity in genotype and the environment as well as interactions between genotype and the environment lead to diverse characteristics, or phenotypes. The REU program will prepare students to meet this challenge by supporting development of their observation skills and their ability to approach complex problems from multiple experimental directions. These skills are required to address challenges such as how organisms respond to stresses and how to target plant and animal breeding to sustainably feed and fuel the growing human population. Students will learn how research is conducted, and many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences. Assessment of the program will be done thru the online SALG URSSA tool. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths.

This REU will train students to understand how observable traits and phenotypes are influenced by genotype and environmental conditions. The program includes diverse projects with research groups from nine bioscience departments (Bacteriology, Biochemistry, Biomolecular Chemistry, Botany, Comparative Biosciences, Entomology, Integrative Biology, Medical Genetics, and Neurology). Students will participate in seminars and workshops to sharpen their research skills of observation, critical thinking, communication, research ethics, and creativity. Students will learn strategies to navigate the research process and will learn ways to develop an effective relationship with their mentors. They will acquire skills and knowledge that will help enhance student success in graduate school. Students should apply online. Applications are reviewed holistically by the PI, Co-PI, and faculty mentor. More information about the program is available by visiting https://wiscience.wisc.edu/IBS-SRP, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Amber Smith at amber.smith@wisc.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. David Wassarman at dawassarman@wisc.edu).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Biological Interactions from Molecules to Ecosystems - Phenotype, Genotype, and Environment Summer Research Program (BI) provided 10-week summer research experiences to 32 students who are interested in graduate study and research careers in biology. The program goals were to 1) Provide authentic, mentored undergraduate research experiences in biology; 2) Diversify the pool of future research scientists; 3) Develop students’ observation skills, understanding of phenotype, and ability to think about a research problem from multiple disciplinary perspectives; 4) Develop students’ social and cultural capital to empower them to navigate the hidden curriculum of research for success in the summer program, in graduate school, and in a future STEM career. 

Students engaged in full time research on projects that explored how the DNA sequence of an organism (genotype) and the environment influence the observable traits (phenotypes) of an organism. Through these research projects, students learned foundational concepts in biology, developed their research and critical thinking skills and cultivated their confidence to be a scientist. The common objectives across all research projects were for students to: 1) understand current scientific literature related to their project, 2) develop testable hypotheses and an experimental design to test them, 3) acquire technical skills to test their hypothesis, 4) interpret results and develop critical thinking, and 5) communicate scientific research outcomes and objectives effectively, both in written and oral forms. The Entering Research and Entering Mentoring curricula were used to guide and support students and mentors in establishing positive relationships and achieving their research project goals together. A team of mentors were in place to support students' development of their research skills and knowledge, scientific communication skills, research self-efficacy, science identity, and independence. 

Student learning was measured through the validated assessment tool (SALG/URSSA) used across all Biology REU programs. The average student learning gains (2021-2024, n=31) based on a scale of 1=no gains to 5=great gain for the four categories were: Thinking and Working Like a Scientist 4.4; Personal Gains Related to Research Work 4.4; Skills 4.1; Attitudes and Behaviors as a Researcher 4.4. Ninety-seven percent of students reported their overall research experience was good or excellent and 87% agreed or strongly agreed the research program helped prepare them for graduate school. Ninety-four percent of students agreed or strongly agreed the research experience confirmed their interest in a field of study, and 74% of students reported they are extremely more likely or much more likely to enroll in a STEM PhD program after participating in the BI program.

The primary broader impact aim of the BI program was to expand research opportunities for students who do not have opportunities at their home institution to engage deeply in research and to explore their curiosities about the natural world. The research experience gained in the program makes students better prepared to pursue graduate or professional degrees in STEM fields and ultimately enter the STEM workforce. Of the 32 students funded on this grant, 47% were first generation college students, 72% were economically disadvantaged backgrounds, and 50% attended non-PhD granting institutions. Of the 89 students funded by NSF from 2015-2023, 69 (76%) have completed their Bachelor's degree and the remaining participants (20) are working on their associates or bachelor's degree. Among those who have completed their Bachelors (n = 69), here are the highest degrees earned or in progress: 26 BA/BS, 1 DDS/DMD, 10 MA/MS, 7 MD, 1 MPH, 21 PhD, and 3 completed post-baccalaureate training programs.
